007 * All rights reserved. Visit https://imagingbook.com for additional details.
008 */
009package imagingbook.common.util;
010
011import java.util.stream.IntStream;
012
013/**
014 * <p>
015 * Determines the 'permutation' of a sequence of numbers and keeps it as an array ({@code perm}) of position indexes.
016 * These indexes indicate how the original input array may be re-ordered to become sorted (see
017 * {@link #getPermutation()}). Implemented only for arrays of type {@code int}, {@code float} and {@code double}.
018 * </p>
019 * <p>
020 * Usage example - get the second-smallest element of a {@code double} array:
021 * </p>
022 * <pre>
023 *      double[] a = ...        // some array
024 *      int k = PrimitiveSortMap.getNthSmallestIndex(a, 1);     // index of 2nd-smallest element
025 *      double x = a[k];
026 * </pre>
027 * <p>
028 * Alternatively, the 2nd-smallest <em>value</em> can be obtained directly by
029 * </p>
030 * <pre>
031 * double x = PrimitiveSortMap.getNthSmallestValue(a, 1);
032 * </pre>
033 *
034 * @author WB
035 * @version 2022/09/15
036 */
037public class PrimitiveSortMap {
038        
039        private final int[] perm;
040        
041        /**
042         * Constructor for {@code double[]}. The input array is not modified.
043         * @param a the input array
044         */
045        public PrimitiveSortMap(double[] a) {
046                this.perm = IntStream.range(0, a.length).boxed()
047                        .sorted((i, j) -> Double.compare(a[i], a[j]))
048                        .mapToInt(x->x.intValue()).toArray();
049        }
050        
051        /**
052         * Constructor for {@code float[]}. The input array is not modified.
053         * @param a the input array
054         */
055        public PrimitiveSortMap(float[] a) {
056                this.perm = IntStream.range(0, a.length).boxed()
057                        .sorted((i, j) -> Float.compare(a[i], a[j]))
058                        .mapToInt(x->x.intValue()).toArray();
059        }
060        
061        /**
062         * Constructor for {@code int[]}. The input array is not modified.
063         * @param a the input array
064         */
065        public PrimitiveSortMap(int[] a) {
066                this.perm = IntStream.range(0, a.length).boxed()
067                        .sorted((i, j) -> Integer.compare(a[i], a[j]))
068                        .mapToInt(x->x.intValue()).toArray();
069        }
070        
071        // --------------------------------------------------
072
073        /**
074         * Returns the permutation (position indexes) for the underlying number sequence as a {@code int} array. That is,
075         * the first value in the returned array is the index of the smallest element in {@code numbers}, the second element
076         * points to the second-smallest element, etc. For example, if the original number sequence (passed to the
077         * constructor) is
078         * <pre>
079         *     double[] a = {50.0, 20.0, 100.0, 120.0, 40.0, -10.0};
080         * </pre>
081         * then the index array produced by
082         * <pre>
083         *     int[] perm = new PrimitiveSortMap(a).getPermutation();
084         * </pre> contains
085         * {@code (5, 1, 4, 0, 2, 3)}. This means that
086         * <pre>
087         *     a[perm[i]] &le; a[perm[i+1]]
088         * </pre>
089         * and thus the sequence
090         * <pre>
091         *     {a[perm[0]], A[perm[1]],..., A[perm[N-1]]}
092         * </pre>
093         * is sorted.
094         *
095         * @return the sorting map (permutation)
096         */
097        public int[] getPermutation() {
098                return this.perm;
099        }
100        
101        /**
102         * Returns the index of the n-th smallest element of the original number sequence
103         * (passed to the constructor),
104         * starting with {@code n = 0}, which returns the index of the smallest element.
105         * 
106         * @param n the index
107         * @return the index of the n-th smallest element in the original number sequence
108         */
109        public int getIndex(int n) {
110                if (n < 0 || n >= perm.length) {
111                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("position index n out of range: " + n);
112                }
113                return perm[n];
114        }
115        
116        // --------------------------------------------------
117        
118        /**
119         * Returns the nth smallest element of the specified array,
120         * starting with n = 0, which returns the smallest 
121         * element of the array.
122         * 
123         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
124         * @param n the index
125         * @return the n-th smallest element
126         */
127        public static double getNthSmallestValue(double[] numbers, int n) {
128                return numbers[getNthSmallestIndex(numbers, n)];
129        }
130        
131        /**
132         * Returns the index of the nth smallest element of the specified array,
133         * starting with n = 0, which returns the smallest element of 
134         * the array.
135         * 
136         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
137         * @param n the index
138         * @return the index of the n-th smallest element
139         */
140        public static int getNthSmallestIndex(double[] numbers, int n) {
141                return new PrimitiveSortMap(numbers).getIndex(n);
142        }
143        
144        /**
145         * Returns the largest element of the specified array.
146         * 
147         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
148         * @return the largest element
149         */
150        public static double getLargestValue(double[] numbers) {
151                return numbers[getLargestIndex(numbers)];
152        }
153        
154        /**
155         * Returns the index of the largest element of the specified array.
156         * 
157         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
158         * @return the index of the largest element
159         */
160        public static int getLargestIndex(double[] numbers) {
161                return getNthSmallestIndex(numbers, numbers.length - 1);
162        }
163        
164        /**
165         * Returns the nth smallest element of the specified array,
166         * starting with n = 0, which returns the smallest element of 
167         * the array.
168         * 
169         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
170         * @param n the index
171         * @return the n-th smallest element
172         */
173        public static float getNthSmallestValue(float[] numbers, int n) {
174                return numbers[getNthSmallestIndex(numbers, n)];
175        }
176        
177        /**
178         * Returns the index of the nth smallest element of the specified array,
179         * starting with n = 0, which returns the smallest element of 
180         * the array.
181         * 
182         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
183         * @param n the index
184         * @return the index of the n-th smallest element
185         */
186        public static int getNthSmallestIndex(float[] numbers, int n) {
187                return new PrimitiveSortMap(numbers).getIndex(n);
188        }
189        
190        /**
191         * Returns the largest element of the specified array.
192         * 
193         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
194         * @return the largest element
195         */
196        public static float getLargestValue(float[] numbers) {
197                return numbers[getLargestIndex(numbers)];
198        }
199        
200        /**
201         * Returns the index of the largest element of the specified array.
202         * 
203         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
204         * @return the index of the largest element
205         */
206        public static int getLargestIndex(float[] numbers) {
207                return getNthSmallestIndex(numbers, numbers.length - 1);
208        }
209        
210        /**
211         * Returns the nth smallest element of the specified {@code int[]},
212         * starting with {@code n = 0}, which returns the smallest element of {@code numbers}.
213         * 
214         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
215         * @param n the index
216         * @return the n-th smallest element of {@code numbers}
217         */
218        public static int getNthSmallestValue(int[] numbers, int n) {
219                return numbers[getNthSmallestIndex(numbers, n)];
220        }
221        
222        /**
223         * Returns the index of the nth smallest element of the specified array,
224         * starting with n = 0, which returns the smallest element of 
225         * the array.
226         * 
227         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
228         * @param n the index
229         * @return the index of the n-th smallest element
230         */
231        public static int getNthSmallestIndex(int[] numbers, int n) {
232                return new PrimitiveSortMap(numbers).getIndex(n);
233        }
234        
235        /**
236         * Returns the largest element of the specified array.
237         * 
238         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
239         * @return the largest element
240         */
241        public static float getLargestValue(int[] numbers) {
242                return numbers[getLargestIndex(numbers)];
243        }
244        
245        /**
246         * Returns the index of the largest element of the specified array.
247         * 
248         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
249         * @return the index of the largest element
250         */
251        public static int getLargestIndex(int[] numbers) {
252                return getNthSmallestIndex(numbers, numbers.length - 1);
253        }
254        
255}
